intro: Neophylum scandens, commonly known as the climbing mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees in tropical and subtropical regions. It has small, oval-shaped leaves that are typically arranged alternately along its slender, twining stems. The plant produces small white or pale yellow flowers, followed by fleshy, berry-like fruits that are often consumed by birds. Its parasitic nature allows it to draw water and nutrients from its host, while still performing photosynthesis. Neophylum scandens plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat, influencing both plant and animal communities.
